document_title: Spaceflight and hind limb unloading induces an arthritic phenotype in knee articular cartilage and menisci of rodents
summary_full: This study investigated the effects of reduced weight-bearing, simulating spaceflight conditions and sedentary lifestyles, on knee articular cartilage and menisci in rodents. Experiments involved mice exposed to spaceflight (ISS and Space Shuttle) and hind limb unloading (HLU), followed by a recovery period with or without exercise. Results showed that both spaceflight and HLU induced an arthritic phenotype, characterized by cartilage thinning and volume loss at the weight-bearing tibial-femoral contact point, and meniscal volume decline. Biochemical analyses revealed decreased glycosaminoglycan content, elevated catabolic enzymes (MMP-13), and increased oxidative stress and catabolic molecular pathways in the menisci. Importantly, exercise during the recovery phase promoted the recovery of cartilage volume and thickness, suggesting a potential therapeutic benefit for joint health in both spaceflight and ground-based scenarios.
key_findings: Reduced weight-bearing from spaceflight (ISS, Shuttle) and hind limb unloading (HLU) in rodents leads to cartilage thinning and volume loss at the tibial-femoral contact point.
Menisci also experience volume decline and reduced glycosaminoglycan content under unloaded conditions.
Spaceflight and HLU induce an arthritic molecular phenotype in menisci, including elevated catabolic enzymes (MMP-13) and increased oxidative stress.
Exercise during the readaptation period following HLU promotes recovery of cartilage thickness and volume.
Running exercise appears more effective than climbing exercise in restoring cartilage thickness and volume after HLU.
future_research_fields: Investigating specific exercise modalities for optimal joint recovery in reduced weight-bearing conditions.
Exploring pharmacological interventions to mitigate spaceflight-induced joint degradation.
Long-term effects of spaceflight and HLU on joint health and the progression to osteoarthritis.
Translating findings to human astronauts and patients with reduced weight-bearing due to sedentary lifestyles or injury.

conclusions: Reduced weight-bearing, whether from spaceflight or hind limb unloading, induces an arthritic phenotype in knee articular cartilage and menisci. This degradation occurs at critical weight-bearing sites and is associated with molecular changes indicative of catabolism and oxidative stress. Importantly, exercise can promote recovery of cartilage structure, suggesting that targeted exercise regimens may be beneficial for maintaining joint health in astronauts and individuals experiencing reduced weight-bearing on Earth.
impact_statement: This study demonstrates that reduced weight-bearing, mimicking spaceflight, causes joint degradation and reveals that exercise can mitigate these effects, offering insights for astronaut health and potential treatments for osteoarthritis.
